medical: EXAM:MRI-UP EXT JOINT LEFT SHOULDER CLINICAL:Left shoulder pain. Evaluate for rotator cuff tear. FINDINGS: Multiple T1 and gradient echo axial images were obtained, as well as T1 and fat suppressed T2-weighted coronal images. The rotator cuff appears intact and unremarkable. There is no significant effusion seen. Osseous structures are unremarkable. There is no significant downward spurring at the acromioclavicular joint. The glenoid labrum is intact and unremarkable. IMPRESSION: Unremarkable MRI of the left shoulder.
layman:
EXAM: MRI of the left shoulder joint  
CLINICAL: The patient has pain in the left shoulder. The doctor wants to check for a rotator cuff tear.  

FINDINGS: The scan used several types of images. The rotator cuff muscles and tendons look normal. There is no large fluid collection in the joint. The bones look normal, and there is no obvious bone spurs at the acromioclavicular joint. The glenoid labrum (the cartilage rim around the shoulder socket) is normal.  

IMPRESSION: The MRI of the left shoulder is normal.
